newsitem.title: ISRAEL: Arafat to renew security contacts with Israel.
newsitem.headline: Arafat to renew security contacts with Israel.

text.p: Palestinian President Yasser Arafat has agreed to resume security contacts with Israel severed last month when the Jewish state broke ground on a new settlement in Arab East Jerusalem, a PLO official said on Saturday.
"President Arafat agreed to renew security coordination with Israel," he said.
The official, who did not want to be identified, said the decision was taken during the visit of U.S. special envoy Dennis Ross to the region this week.
The PLO cut off security contacts with Israel when it began work on a Jewish settlement in East Jerusalem, dealing the peace process one of its most serious setbacks since its launch in 1991.

The construction sparked widespread clashes between Palestinian stone-throwers and Israeli troops in the West Bank. Three days after the building began a Palestinian bomber killed three Israeli women at a Tel Aviv cafe.
Arafat had said earlier he would renew security cooperation only after Israel agreed to freeze the settlement plan.
Ross, who is on his way back to Washington, managed to get Israeli and Palestinian security chiefs to meet to discuss security cooperation.
U.S. President Bill Clinton said on Friday it was vital to keep pressing ahead to bring the sides together.
"The important thing is we get this security cooperation up and going and then we just keep plugging ahead," Clinton told reporters at a briefing in the White House.
